Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Clot \Clot\, v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Clotted}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Clotting}.] To concrete, coagulate, or thicken, as soft or fluid matter by evaporation; to become a cot or clod. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Clot \Clot\, v. t. To form into a slimy mass. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Clot \Clot\ (kl[o^]t), n. [OE. clot, clodde, clod; akin to D. kloot ball, G. kloss clod, dumpling, klotz block, Dan. klods, Sw. klot bowl, globe, klots block; cf. AS. cl[=a]te bur. Cf. {Clod}, n., {Clutter} to clot.] A concretion or coagulation; esp. a soft, slimy, coagulated mass, as of blood; a coagulum. ``Clots of pory gore.'' --Addison. [1913 Webster]
Doth bake the egg into clots as if it began to poach. --Bacon. [1913 Webster]
Note: Clod and clot appear to be radically the same word, and are so used by early writers; but in present use clod is applied to a mass of earth or the like, and clot to a concretion or coagulation of soft matter. [1913 Webster]

clot n : a lump of material formed from the content of a liquid [syn: {coagulum}] v 1: change from a liquid to a thickened or solid state; "coagulated blood" [syn: {coagulate}] 2: cause to change from a liquid to a solid or thickened state [syn: {coagulate}] 3: turn into curds; "curdled milk" [syn: {curdle}, {clabber}] [ant: {homogenize}, {homogenize}, {homogenize}] 4: coalesce or unite in a mass; "Blood clots" [syn: {clog}] [also: {clotting}, {clotted}]
